sections.heading: Abstract
sections.text:
In this study, five polysaccharides were applied as natural polymeric coating materials to prepare solid lipid nanoparticles (SLN) and nanostructure lipid carriers (NLC), and then the obtained lipid particles were transformed to solid powders by the innovative nano spray drying technology. The feasibility and suitability of this new technology to generate ultra-fine lipid powder particles were evaluated and the formulation was optimized. The spray dried SLN powder exhibited the aggregated and irregular shape and dimension, but small, uniform, wellseparated spherical powder particles of was obtained from NLC. The optimal formulation of NLC was prepared by a 20-30% oleic acid content with carrageenan or pectin as coating material. Therefore, nano spray drying technology has a potential application to produce uniform, spherical, and sub-microscale lipid powder particles when the formulation of lipid delivery system is appropriately designed. Keywords: Nano spray drying; solid lipid nanoparticles; nanostructured lipid carriers; polysaccharide; coating.
Solid lipid nanoparticles (SLN) and nanostructure lipid carriers (NLC) are the two most studied lipid-based formulations and have the great potential to be generic delivery systems for drugs and nutrients, owing to their low toxicity, high loading capacity, slow release rate, and excellent stability (Fathi et al., 2012; Müller et al., 2000). SLN is prepared by emulsifying saturated fatty acids (e.g. stearic acid) or physiological lipids (e.g. triglycerides) at a temperature 5-10 ºC higher than their melting point, followed by re-crystallization at a lower temperature to solidify the nanoscale lipid droplets. NLC is prepared similarly by replacing a certain percentage (usually from 5% - 40%) of solid fat with liquid fat, i.e. unsaturated fatty acids or oils. Both SLN and NLC have been extensively studied for their drug delivery applications.
Despite many promising features of lipid-based formations as delivery vehicles, a longstanding historical challenge yet to be solved before industrialization and commercialization. Due to the high hydrophobicity and poor solubility of lipids, drying processes can easily induce severe aggregation, agglomeration or melting of lipid and thus dramatically destroy the structures of SLN (Mehnert and Mäder, 2001). For instance, during lyophilization, the slow rate removal of water from SLN dispersion will comprise the effects of surfactants and eventually causing aggregation of particles. In this case, a high concentration of cryoprotectant (10-20%), is needed and meanwhile the SLN concentration in a dispersion should not exceed 5% (Schwarz and Mehnert, 1997; Siekmann and Westesen, 1994). Otherwise, a significant increase in particle size after drying would occur. Alternatively, spray drying is another widely studied technology to transform an aqueous SLN dispersion into a dry product. However, high temperature (such as 100 ºC) and strong shear force are often required in spray drying process. These conditions significantly elevate the kinetic energy leading to frequent particle collision and melting of lipids. Finally, irregular-shaped lipid crystals at micro-size scale are obtained. It has been reported that
in order to generate regular-shaped SLN powder particles (approx. 3 µm in diameter), up to 30% trehalose must be included in the original SLN formulation (Freitas and Müller, 1998).
Nano spray drying is an emerging technology recently invented by Büchi® in 2010. This technology utilizes a vibration mesh spray technology to create millions of tiny droplets that are quickly dried by a laminar heating flow, which is designed to provide gentle heating with inlet temperature ranging from 0 C to 120 C. The functional principle is illustrated in Figure 1. Specifically, this technology is extremely ideal for heat-sensitive biopharmaceutical products. Thus far, both protein- and polysaccharide-based formulations have been evaluated by this technology (Lee et al., 2011; Li et al., 2010), however, lipid-based products, such as SLN and NLC, are yet to be systematically evaluated. Our previous study successfully demonstrated the feasibility of this technology to produce nanoscale powders from pectin/low density lipoprotein nanogels dispersion, avoiding the irreversible gelation that would occur during traditional spray drying process (Zhou et al., 2016). We have further applied this novel technology to develop instant functional drink powder mix from a pectin/casein nanocomplex-based colloidal nutrient delivery system (Wang et al., 2016) as well as redispersible essential oil nanoemulsion spherical powder particles (200-500 nm) from gum arabic-based colloidal dispersion (Hu et al., 2016). Therefore, nano spray drying technology was comprehensively evaluated in this work for its suitability to produce ultra-fine powders of SLN and NLC. To prepared stable SLN and NLC with minimal toxicity, polysaccharides were exploited as natural and safe coating material and their coating effects on lipids particles during spray drying were evaluated.
SLN was prepared from Compritol® 888 ATO (Gattefossé, France) by a novel approach combining hot homogenization and solvent diffusion process as described elsewhere (Luo et al., 2015). Briefly, 80 mg solid lipid was dissolved in 5 mL of ethanol/acetone (1:1) (Fisher
Scientific Co., Pittsburgh, USA) and heated to 80 ºC, and then added into 100 mL aqueous phase containing different polysaccharides at 0.4 mg/mL and lecithin at 0.5 mg/mL, followed by sonication for 3 min and cooling in ice bath. NLC was prepared similarly by replacing solid lipid with 10-40 wt% oleic acid (purity 97%, Fisher Scientific Co., Pittsburgh, USA), while keeping the aqueous phase the same.
Five types of polysaccharides were exploited in this work, i.e. pectin, gum arabic, alginate, carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC, 90,000 Da) and carrageenan. The particle size, polydispersity index (PDI) and zeta potential of original SLN and NLC dispersions were first determined by dynamic light scattering (DLS) using a Nano ZetaSizer ZS model (Malvern Instruments, Ltd., Worcestershire, UK). Results indicated that different polysaccharides have different capability to coat lipid and oil (Figure 2). Generally, lipid particles, either SLN or NLC, that were coated by pectin and gum arabic had smaller size and more homogeneous size distribution (smaller PDI), approximate 200 nm and 0.25, respectively. NLC with 30% oil content had the smallest particle size for any of the five polysaccharide coating. It is notable that particles prepared with alginate had the largest size (250 – 300 nm) and PDI (0.3 – 0.5), as well as the most negative zeta potential (-85 – -80 mV). The zeta potentials of all lipid particles were from -50 – -80 mV, indicating the strong repulsion among particles in these dispersions, i.e. excellent colloidal stability.
Then, all samples were subject to spray drying by a Nano Spray Dryer B-90 (Büchi Labortechnik AG, Flawil, Switzerland), with the following operating conditions: inlet temperature at 100 ºC, flow rate at 120 L/min, mesh size at 5.5 µm. The morphology of obtained powders was captured by a scanning electron microscope (JSM-6330F, JEOL Ltd., Tokyo, Japan). As shown in Figure 3, both the type of polysaccharide and the content of oil had
significant effects on the morphology of spray dried lipid particles. Generally, SLN exhibited more agglomerated particles with severe aggregation, compared to NLC powders. The extent of agglomeration/aggregation became less as the increase of oil content. The production of SLN is due to the formation of highly crystalline lipid core during cooling of emulsified hot lipid nanoemulsion, while the crystallization process itself has a tendency to cause aggregation and form larger particles. During spray drying process, the lipid particles are being heated up to 100 °C (higher than lipid melting point) and therefore the lipid core can easily aggregate when re-crystallization occurs as the temperature slowly goes down in the drying chamber. Nevertheless, the lipid core of NLC is amorphous at all times due to the inclusion of liquid oil, which solidifies in the solid but not crystalline during spray drying process (Fang et al., 2008; Müller et al., 2002). Therefore, the smaller and more well-separated particles were obtained for the NLC samples with higher oil content. Notably, when the oil content increased to 40%, the NLC powder had sticky texture and became less separated particles under SEM. This may be explained by the insufficient dryness and incomplete solidification of NLC dispersion due to high content of liquid fat. Among five polysaccharides, carrageenan exhibited the best effect on producing small, spherical, and well-separated powders, followed by pectin, alginate, CMC, and gum arabic. Even though the liquid dispersion of carrageenan coated NLC showed a relatively large PDI (0.35 – 0.40), the nano spray dried powder was the most uniform in its dimension among all samples. Interestingly, when the oil content was 30% and 40%, the NLC prepared with gum arabic appeared to form an oily film after spray drying. This may be in part ascribed to the high surface active features of gum arabic and its affinities with the oily components of NLC, resulting in droplet flocculation and destruction during drying process. Our observation is in
agreement with a previous study on nano spray drying of nanoemulsion prepared with gum arabic (Li et al., 2010).
In conclusion, five polysaccharides were successfully applied as coating material to prepare stable SLN and NLC, without any synthetic surfactants. NLC was prepared by replacing solid lipid with oleic acid, up to 40%. While similar trend in the change of particle size was found among SLN and NLC prepared with different polysaccharides, each polysaccharide demonstrated distinct effects on the characteristics of lipid particles. Nano spray drying technology was evaluated as a novel technique to produce ultra-fine particle powders of SLN and NLC. The major findings indicated that both the type of polysaccharide and the oil (oleic acid) content played critical roles in determining the final morphology of the powders. While particles without aggregation cannot be obtained from SLN via nano spray drying, small, uniform, and spherical powder particles can be produced from NLC if appropriate polysaccharides and oil contents are formulated. Collectively, carrageenan and pectin are the two optimal polysaccharides and 20 – 30% oil content is the ideal formulation for NLC to achieve the ultrafine lipid particle powders by nano spray drying technology.
